items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: Levels are falling, but still remain quite high in some locations. A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area. Higher water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea of the Broads river system at low tide. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and update you as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Wednesday the 2nd of February, and the flood alert may need to stay in force for the next few days.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday the 3rd of February.

items.description: Northumberland coast
items.message: The risk of flooding from the North Sea at Beadnell Harbour Road North and Newbiggin Bay North Promenade has now reduced. Tide levels are reducing and there is no surge forecast. No further flooding to coastal areas is expected, however there may still be debris on roads that have been flooded. For a 5 day flood risk forecast please see the GOV.UK website or for a weather forecast see the Met Office website.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today Wednesday the 2nd of February, and the flood alert may need to stay in force for the next few days.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday the 3rd of February.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.6mAOD at 03:00 on 02/02/22 and 4.67mAOD at 15:45 on 02/02/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 33 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 02/02/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast at North Morecambe Bay
items.message: This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon on 02/02/2022 between 11:00 AM and 01:00 PM.  Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale.  We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, the tide at 12:44 PM on Thursday 03/02/2022 will exceed flood alert level. The earlier high tide at 00:30 on Thursday 03/02/2022 is not expected to reach flood alert level. 
Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected 2 hours before and after the high tide at lunchtime on 03/02/2022.
We are within a cycle of high tides and as a result we may issue further alerts over the coming days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming high tides.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry between 12:45 PM and 01:15 PM, Eastford Road and Arpley Bridge between 01:15 PM and 01:45 PM on 02/02/2022. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 4 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. The high tide on Wednesday evening 02/02/2022 is not expected to reach flood alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 03/02/2022, or as the situation changes.
